Comment: Sequence of numbers. Examples: HMC310 25303763146288737718903, RC100.2 H 05704801002367738112973, MX300 25303394051798738806124. This block contains production information of the electronics module (e.g. ACU-LO ACU-MH HRV_CU etc.) ASCII encoded '\0' terminated.  **Note1**: A reader should always ask for *part1* first. *part2* needs to be requested only in case the production information string in *part1* does not contain the '\0' terminator! **Note2**: In case *part2* needs to be requested the '\0' termination is located at the end of the string (somewhere in *part2*) i.e. *part1* does NOT contain the '\0' terminator. **Note3**: Byte-0 at index 0 is the first character of the string. **Note4**: Legacy products support only *part1* and the content is coded depending on the product (e.g. ASCII coded for Nefit/Buderus or BCD coded for Junkers).

Should be \0 terminated, but is not always. i.e. Heat Pump responds with 43 55 48 50 ='CUHP', but \0 is missing. The product name corresponds with the identification byte defined in telegram 2 offset 0.  **Note**: String formatted as ASCII '\0' terminated.

Some devices send more data after offset 43. Either a series of 00 or FF. This block contains production information of the electronics module (e.g. ACU-LO ACU-MH HRV_CU etc.). ASCII encoded '\0' terminated.  **Note1**: A reader should always ask for *part1* first. *part2* needs to be requested only in case the production information string in *part1* does not contain the '\0' terminator. **Note2**: In case *part2* needs to be requested the '\0' termination is always at the end of the string (somewhere in *part2*) i.e. *part1* does NOT contain the '\0' terminator. The reader of telegram 1 has to properly concatenate the received content of *part2* (until the '\0' terminator) with the received content of *part1* to get the final string. **Note3**: Legacy products support only *part1* and the content is coded depending on the product (e.g. ASCII coded for Nefit/Buderus or BCD coded for Junkers).

Major software version. Shows major changes to Hard- and Software. 0 is development.
Minor software version. Indicates minor changes to Hard- and Software. For instance small bug fixes. During the development, this value is incremented as well.

Variable_Name: 2nd Identification byte of indirect bus member
Comment: In some systems, this is the identification byte of the integrated *burner module*.

Variable_Name: 2nd Version number of indirect bus member (Before column).
Comment: In some systems, this is the major version of the integrated *burner module*.

Variable_Name: 2nd Version number of indirect bus member (After column).
Comment: In some systems, this is the minor version of the integrated *burner module*.

Variable_Name: 3rd Identification byte of indirect bus member
3rd version byte of indirect bus member (Before column)
3rd Version number of indirect bus member (After column)
Comment: **Junkers**: *Fx system* interprets this byte as Feature ID. Due to expansion of some new functionalities a feature marking should be implemented. This marking has to be transmitted on EMS bus after power-up and on request. telegram 2 offset 3-7 shall be filled with '0x00'.  In telegram 2 offset 8 the so called 'FeatureID' must be added:     - ISM software which supports 'Solar system 4 and Solar option F' => telegram 2 offset 8 = 0x64 = 100     - IPM software which supports 'Actuator tests' => telegram 2 offset 8 = 0x64 = 100

Specifies the brand of a module.  A module can use this information to block communication or to adapt to the master slave inverse if required. No_brand_identification = 0, Bosch = 1, Junkers = 2, Buderus = 3, Nefit = 4, Sieger = 5, Tata = 6, Dakon = 7, Elm = 8, Boulter = 9, Vulcano = 10, Worcester = 11, British_Gas = 12, IVT = 13, Geminox = 14, Neckar = 15, Zeus = 16, Milton = 17

Delivered from ACU for DNA2 HMIs. Content: country code following the `ISO3166-1 <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_3166-1>`_ standard in numeric code format e.g. Germany = 'DE' = '276' on EMS. UNDEFINED = 0
Some appliances return a series of 00 or FF
90=error reset, also 153 and 245 do a reset (maybe on a different level)
85=activate if standby can be selected in the menu, 170=deactivate, status is visible in 0x00E4 offset 12.0
numbers >= 200, list used in Nefit and Buderus
Bit 7 (=1) of this number indicates if the year is absolute. Bit 7=0 indicates relative time, then is offset 4 is unused
Offset 4 Bit 7=1 indicates that this offset 5 is the absolute month. Offset 4 Bit 7=0 indicates relative time. Then the uptime in minutes is stored in offset 5-7
Offset 4 Bit 7=1 indicates that this offset 6 is the absolute hour. Offset 4 Bit 7=0 indicates relative time. Then the uptime in minutes is stored in offset 5-7
Offset 4 Bit 7=1 indicates that this offset 7 is the absolute day. Offset 4 Bit 7=0 indicates relative time. Then the uptime in minutes is stored in offset 5-7
Offset 4 Bit 7=1 indicates that this offset 7 is the absolute minute. Offset 4 Bit 7=0 indicates relative time. Then the offset 8 is empty

0=Mode1 (I1 closed, I4 open = Heat pump blocked by energy supplier); 1=Mode2 (I1 open, I4 open = Normal operation); 2=Mode3 (I1 open, I4 closed = Heatpump prefered); 3=Mode4 (I1 closed, I4 closed = Forced operation of heatpump)

1 = No predefined settings. Minimum pump speed telegram 0x16,offset 10 and maximum pump speed telegram 0x16 offset 9 manually adjustable; 2-7 = Constant speeds (minimum pump speed telegram 0x16 offset 10 and maximum pump speed telegram 0x16 offset 9 are the same). 8-10 = Predefined minimum pump speed 0x16 offset 10 and maximum pump speed 0x16 offset 9 settings.
auto = 0, according burner = 1, acc room temp control = 2, acc outdoor temp control = 3, acc outdoor temp control optimized = 4, energy saving = 4, acc CH heat request = 5

CAN:824 COMPRESSOR_ALARMS_StopCompressor COMPRESSOR_ALARMS_E21_OutDoorTempBlocked The corresponding bit indicates which limit is exceeded and causes blocking. If no blocking active all bits = 0. Evaluation is based on outdoor temperature. Bit 0: Min temp for heating (< -21°C restart at -17°C) Bit 1: Max temp for heating (> 36°C restart at 33°C) Bit 2: Min temp for cooling (< 14°C restart at 17°C) Bit 3: Max temp for cooling (> 46°C restart at 44°C)

CAN:813 Summary alarm A1 COMPRESSOR_ALARMS_E21_Summary_A1 If error/alarm flags are set heat pump is blocked and waiting for acknowlede Error flags will be set in ODU if error occurs multiple times or for more than 15min. Bit0: PH1 sensor error Bit1: PL1 sensor error Bit2: High pressure Bit3: High temperature alarm Bit4: Low temperature alarm Bit5: Max hot gas alarm Bit6: Frost protection alarm Bit7: Low overheating alarm Bit8: Inverter IPM over current Bit9: Compressor driving error Bit10: Compressor over current Bit11: PFC over current peak Bit12: IPM module over heat Bit13: Compressor model error Bit14: Inverter HP switch Bit15: Four-way-valve alarm cooling

CAN:814 Summary alarm A2 COMPRESSOR_ALARMS_E21_Summary_A2 If error/alarm flags are set heat pump is blocked and waiting for acknowlede. Error flags will be set in ODU if error occurs multiple times or for more than 15min. Bit0: Four-way-valve alarm heating Bit1: Node adress alarm (not used) Bit2: Hose connection mixed error (The input and outlet hoses are mixed between the IDU and ODU) Bit3: Defrost high delta error (To high delta between flow and return temp during defrosting) Bit4: Clean outdoor unit PH1 (Evaporator is blocked cleaning of ODU might be needed) Bit5: Clean outdoor unit PL1 (Evaporator is blocked cleaning of ODU might be needed) Bit6: Drip pan heater alarm (pan heater does not work) Bit7: Drip pan blocked alarm (drip pan outlet is blocked) Bit8: not used Bit9: not used Bit10: not used Bit11: not used Bit12: not used Bit13: not used Bit14: not used Bit15: not used

CAN:815 Summary alarm B1 COMPRESSOR_ALARMS_E21_Summary_B1 If error/alarm flags are set heat pump is blocked - no waiting for acknowlede.  Bit0: PH1 sensor error Bit1: PL1 sensor error Bit2: High pressure Bit3: High temperature alarm Bit4: Low temperature alarm Bit5: Max hot gas alarm Bit6: Frost protection alarm Bit7: Low overheating alarm Bit8: Inverter IPM over current Bit9: Compressor driving error Bit10: Compressor over current Bit11: PFC over current peak Bit12: IPM module over heat Bit13: Compressor model error Bit14: Inverter HP switch Bit15: Four-way-valve alarm cooling

CAN:816 Summary alarm B2 COMPRESSOR_ALARMS_E21_Summary_B2 If error/alarm flags are set heat pump is blocked. No waiting for acknowlede.  Bit0: Four-way-valve alarm heating (Four way valve does not switch from heating to cooling) Bit1: Internal inverter alarm Bit2: T6 sensor error Bit3: T7 sensor error Bit4: T21 sensor error Bit5: T12 sensor error Bit6: T23 sensor error Bit7: T24 sensor error Bit8: T25 sensor error Bit9: Compressor start error Bit10: Inverter communication error Bit11: no power to heat pump error Bit12: Phase to inverter missing error  Bit13: Too high input voltage error Bit14: Too low input voltage error Bit15: Inverter overheated error

CAN:817 Summary alarm C1 COMPRESSOR_ALARMS_E21_Summary_C1 Non blocking error/alarms. No waiting for acknowlede.  Bit0: T6 sensor error Bit1: T7 sensor error Bit2: T21 sensor error Bit3: T12 sensor error Bit4: T23 sensor error Bit5: T24 sensor error Bit6: T25 sensor error Bit7: T26 sensor error Bit8: Fan alarm Bit9: Inverter communication disturbed Bit10: Frost alarm Bit11: Too much refrigerant error Bit12: Lack of refrigerant error  Bit13: Too high input voltage error Bit14: Clean outdoor unit Bit15: Defrost failure warning

Variable_Name: DHW immediately request for DHW System I
DHW immediately request for DHW System II

Comment: The 3 highest are stored (Max function). The highest is used. The EMS enables 100% power unless it is limited by DT22I2 (max).

The 3 highest are stored. The highest is used. The EMS sets the temperature setpoint to 90°C unless it is limited by DT22I1 (max).  Remark: The Temperature and power setpoint are independent from each other.  It is not necessary to sent them together (Power and Supply temperature setpoint).  When they do come together the highest of both will be used. Note (See table below):  1) UBA3.  2) MC10/HTIII.  Behaviour for future developments for note 1) and 2) must be defined.  When both the power and supply setpoint are transmitted then both must be zero for no heat demand and both > 0 for a heat demand.  Avoid to transmit both setpoints with one of them zeroed. If Powersetpoint == not transmitted AND SupplyTempSetpoint == not transmitted Result = boiler dependent  If Powersetpoint == not transmitted AND SupplyTempSetpoint == 0°C Result = No heat demand  If Powersetpoint == not transmitted AND SupplyTempSetpoint == 60°C Result: T=60°C; P=max  If Powersetpoint == 0% AND SupplyTempSetpoint == not transmitted Result = No heat demand  If Powersetpoint == 0% AND SupplyTempSetpoint == 0°C Result = No heat demand  If Powersetpoint == 0% AND SupplyTempSetpoint == 60°C Results: UBA3: Temp=60°C; Power=max MC10/HTIII: no heat demand  If Powersetpoint == 80% AND SupplyTempSetpoint == not transmitted Result: T=max; P=80%  If Powersetpoint == 80% AND SupplyTempSetpoint == 0°C Results: UBA3: T=max; P=80% MC10/HTIII: no heat demand  If Powersetpoint == 80% AND SupplyTempSetpoint == 60°C Result: T=60°C; P=80%

Enables the boiler to pre heat with the highest possible efficiency.  The three lowest variables are stored (of different tokens) of which the lowest variable will be used.  When this function is activated without a set point (Power = 0 and Supply Temperature = 0) being transmitted  the maximum values of both set points will be used by the heat supplier.  The control algorithm of the heat supplier (i.e. the heat pump) always limits both set points only if they exceed the high efficiency set points.

Variable_Name: Heating circuit temperature level for pump save function.
Comment: Depending on the required heating circuit temperature level the pump will be switched off more or less often in order to save energy.  The 3 highest are stored.  The highest is used.  0: None. The internal setting will be used in this case.  1: Frost.  2: Low.  3: High. not used for Buderus xLow can use DT26 I4: high => roomtemp setpoint != off; frost: if roomtep setpoint ==off

The BCM numbers for EMS will start with 1000, to prevent mismatches with UBA1 numbers (0-255). The BIM numbers will start with 5000. The HTIII coding module range: 11000 – 14352 (real codeplug number + an offset of 10000). The WB-Dev based applications have the range: 20000 - 29999, refined in detail:    - CU-PF:   20000-24999    - ACU_Lo:  25000-28999    - Special: 29000-29999 Special:    - RI:34 - 45    - LPP, LPP-Bu: 84 - 87 and 148 - 151  **Important**: - Default value: 0xFFFF (no codeplug) - If a product doesn't have a BCM, it shall report 0xFFFF as BCM number. This number is then reported/forwarded by the connectivity gateway to the backend. The product that has no BCM shall additionally mark this index as *unused* (see telegram 247 data handling). - A connectivity gateway can still report 0x0000 as value towards the backend, in case the product does not support the BCM number (i.e. telegram 4 offset 0-1 is not transmitted on EMS).
Under the same BCM number small changes can be made. (UBA 1 has a safety and a miscellaneous version number)
- 0 = modulating burner - 1-7 = stages of the burner MODULATING = 0

Maximal power for Central Heating in kW (maximale Leistung).  This value must be consistent with value calculated from ['Maximum appliance power' (telegram 4 offset 25-26) times 'Maximum relative power CH' (telegram 4 offset 23)]. Domestic Hot Water can have another maximum. Used if power <=255kW; **High byte**: telegram 4 offset 12 - Must be supported for legacy reasons.

For a boiler the max. appliance power and max. CH power can be different! This minimal burner load value is based on max. CH power for UBA/CUx and on max. appliance power for HT3/MC10 /ACUs (same as telegram 4 offset 22).

Under this temperature the pump will be switched off when the burner is on. When the burner is on it will stay on for at least that this temperature (+hysteresis 5K) is reached.  *Note*: Only for floor standing boilers.

When there is a heat request and the boiler temperature is below this value the burner will switch on. The set point for the temperature controller will be lifted up when this function is active. *Note*: Only for floor standing boilers.
This value can be used in automatic cascade controller where a preference for efficiency is chosen.

A fixed power limitation in the field is still needed. On the UBA 1 it was the 11 kW jumper.  This function is changed to a fixed power limitation. The power limit is stored in the BCM and depends on the boiler. For instance for boilers up to 32 kW the limit is 11 kW for boilers up to 70 kW it can be 50 kW. The limited CH power can be read in the Boiler identification block. 0 = off, -1 = on

0: No pump available.    When the pump is removed from the boiler this value can be set to no. The pump relay will never be switched on even when a request comes over the bus.  1: Internal pump. Normal CH pump (Factory setting). During a central heating or a hot water demand and in the post purge time the EMS will control the pump. During the other moments the bus settings will be used.  2: External pump. No pump available inside the boiler. Central heating group 1 will use the (external) pump and the controller of this group has to activate this pump. The EMS only activates this pump if a Burner test (Abgastest) is active or when a central heating demand from the on/off room thermostat (RTH switch) is active. NO = 0, INTERNAL = 1, EXTERNAL = 2
0 – 60: Normal post purge time in minutes.  61: Post purge time is 24 hours. 24_Hours = 61

Only possible if a dialog pump is available (see telegram 4, offset 11, bit0).  Options other than option 0 will keep the pressure difference at a constant level. 0 = Normal modulating pump function 1 = Low 2 = Standard 3 = High 4 = Extra high 5 = Maximal 6-8 = Free, MODULATING = 0, DELTA_P_1 = 1, DELTA_P_2 = 2, DELTA_P_3 = 3, DELTA_P_4 = 4, DELTA_P_5 = 5, DELTA_P_6 = 6, Delta_P_7 = 7, Delta_P_8 = 8
Switching off limit for two stage burners.
Switching off limit for two stage burners.
If the temperature is hotter then the setpoint and only 1 stage is on  this limit will be used by the integral for switching the burner on/off.
If the temperature is hotter then the setpoint and 2 stages are on  this limit will be used by the integral for switching the burner on/off. Only used in two stage burners.
If the temperature is hotter then the setpoint and 2 stages are on  this limit will be used by the integral for switching the burner on/off.  Only used in two stage burners.
If the temperature is colder then the setpoint and the burner is off  this limit will be used by the integral for switching the burner on/off.
After switching on or on a stage the integral for switching the burner on/off uses its own setpoint for this time.
After switching on or off a stage the integral for switching the burner on/off is not counted for this time.
If the temperature is with speed or faster approaching the setpoint  the integral for switching the burner on/off is not counted for this time.
This factor changes the setpoint of the fanspeed at minimum power. The amount of change depends on the boiler. If the bit in telegram 4,offset 11,b4 is set, you can change this factor.
This factor changes the setpoint of the fanspeed at maximum power. The amount of change depends on the boiler. If the bit in telegram 4,offset 11,b4 is set, you can change this factor.
If the bit in telegram 4,offset 15,b0 is set, you can change the operating temperature.  The value will send under telegram 4,offset 7 too, but in telegram 4 you can’t change any parameter.

The burner controller only acts as a server for this variable and stores it non volatile. When the system is in manual mode, the human interface will periodically send the Manual Mode setpoint  (as it is stored in telegram 22,offset 26) trough telegram 26,offset 0. 0x00 = Disabled, 0xFF = Enabled, 0 = off, -1 = on

The burner controller only acts as a server for this variable and stores it non volatile. This is the setpoint used during manual mode, which is enabled with telegram 22,offset 25. The value may be altered using the human interface.  The initial value is obtained from the HCM and may be brand/boiler specific.

Resistive system present This function is created for appliances with a modulating pump and modulating burner load.  In cases when the appliance has been installed within a small central heating (CH) system  the system resistance can become too high.  High resistance in a heating system can cause the temperature difference across the system to increase. High resistance in a CH system can be recognized by a larger temperature delta between the supply and the return. In case a certain delta limit will be exceed after a debounce time  the pump speed must be increased with a fixed step to overcome the system resistance and reduce the temperature delta. After a defined time the result of the increased pump speed must be checked based on the temperature delta. 0 = OFF, -1 = ON
